Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Age-Dating M31's Halo and Satellites - Testing the Lambda CDM Paradigm
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stellar halos, the roughly spherical clould of stars orbiting a spiral galaxy, provide unique insight into the formation and evolution of galaxies, and they may hold the key to understanding dark matter. From our position inside the Milky Way, we are unable to fully probe our own halo, because much of it is blocked from our view. M31 (the "Andromeda Galaxy") is near enough that we can measure properties of individual stars in its halo. This program will utilize existing data and obtain new observations of M31 in order to map the distribution star ages throughout its halo. This will permit them to determine the relative importance of several different mechanisms that can add stars to a galaxy halo. Ultimately, this will lead to a better understanding of the history of our own Milky Way galaxy. This program will create opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate student research at two institutions. The University of Virginia group works with amateur astronomers on galaxy evolution research projects and outreach programs to K-12 students in rural Virginia. The University of California - Santa Cruz team teaches underrepresented high school students through the COSMOS, MAGIC, and the Science Internship Programs. Both of the PIs teach large undergraduate courses, actively mentor students, give regular public lectures and speak in K-12 classrooms.

The PIs will create the first age-distribution profile of the M31 stellar halo. This work leverages an enormous investment of telescope time over the past 10 years (the SPLASH project) and aims to add two significant new parameters: metallicity and age distributions. Three new observational methods will be applied, including a near infrared imaging survey across the M31 halo out to a distance of 180 kpc, optical time series of anomalous Cepheids in M31 satellite galaxies, and Keck/DEIMOS spectroscopy of M31 field and dSph stars. POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the life of this award (9/1/2014?8/31/2018), there have been several significant project outcomes and findings both on the intellectual merit front and on the broader impacts front.

Intellectual Merit

The research team and research program funded by this NSF award has demonstrated that M31's stellar halo — and probably the stellar halos of all large galaxies — extends out to to a projected radius of R ~ 200 kpc. This research has also revealed rich substructure in M31's stellar halo. Chemical abundance and kinematical measurements of the smooth halo, halo substructure, and dwarf satellites have revealed a clearer picture than ever before of galaxy formation in our astronomical backyard. The result of these studies is the emergence of a beautiful storyline – one that is perfectly consistent with the Lambda CDM paradigm of the assembly of galactic halos from the merging/destruction of dwarf satellites and their associated smaller dark matter subhalos. Measurements of the internal kinematics of the existing intact satellites of M31 indicates that they are increasingly dark matter dominated with decreasing luminosity/mass as is the case for Milky Way dwarf satelltes and other dwarf galaxies in the Local Volume. This M31 research project has also revealed a lovely relationship between dwarf galaxy mass and chemical abundance – the so-called mass-metallicity relation.

Broader Impacts

This NSF-funded M31 research program has had a signficant set of broader impacts. A large number of postdocs, graduate students, undergraduate students, and high school students have engaged in the research. Close mentoring by senior researchers and careful attention to professional development of young scientists have been the hallmarks of this M31 research program. High school students have been introduced to critical thinking in the context of open-ended, cutting-edge, university-level STEM research projects through the innovative Science Internship Program (SIP) at UCSC. PI Guhathakurta founded the program and continues to serve as its faculty director. The Global SPHERE Network, a community of practice for STEM researchers who engage high school students in their research, was launched in Fall 2017. The PyaR (Python and Research) programming tutorial was developed last year and is set in the context of (and directly derived from) an M31 journal article that was funded by this research grant.
